title: 'Impossible to track': Government outsourcing under fire
text:
"Last week's Senate estimates hearings did not provide any reassurance that the Morrison government is willing to be open and transparent about how much taxpayers’ money is being spent on external consultants.

"The current system of reporting expenditure on external contractors and consultants across the Australian public service is opaque, unreliable and almost impossible to track."

Defence numbers scrutinised

Defence’s annual report says the department entered into just 331 consulting contracts worth $142 million in 2018-19 but provides no detail on the companies providing the services. The document instead refers readers to the government’s AusTender database for details of individual contracts and suppliers.

But an examination of the database shows the department entered into almost $1.6 billion worth of contracts categorised as some form of consulting service, but not tagged as consultancy.

Defence maintains the published figures are correct. The department has more consultants, contractors and labour-hire staff than public sector workers.

Mr Hill said Australians deserved to know where taxpayer dollars were spent and called on the Coalition to be more forthcoming.

The previous inquiry, chaired by Liberal senator Dean Smith, received more than 100 submissions and held three days of public hearings but decided not to issue a report before the election.

Advertisement

"If this government continues to limit the capability of the public service, at the very least Australians need to be assured that the work being done to support the business of government by external contractors is value for money and reported in line with community expectations," Mr Hill said.

Finance Minister Mathias Cormann told Senate estimates hearings last week that the cost of government administration, including contractors and consultants, had decreased under the Coalition.

The data he cited was based on reports derived using the consultancy tag in AusTender.

He said as a proportion of total government spending, consulting costs had decreased from 8.5 per cent in 2007-08 to 7 per cent in 2018-19.

"I expect it to further decrease to 5.4 per cent by 2022-23," Senator Cormann told a Senate committee.
description: Labor wants a parliamentary inquiry into the government's $50 billion outsourcing bill reopened, after it lapsed without issuing a report before the May election.
